notes:
1. Corrosion

Corrosion is the gradual destruction of a material, usually a metal, by chemical or electrochemical reaction with its environment. It is an oxidation process. The most common example is the rusting of steel.

2. Methods of Corrosion Control

Several methods are used to prevent or slow down corrosion:

  • Material Selection: Choosing a material that is naturally resistant to corrosion in the service environment (e.g., using stainless steel, aluminum, or polymers instead of plain carbon steel).
  • Protective Coatings: Applying a barrier between the metal and the environment. This includes painting, powder coating, or plating with a more resistant metal (e.g., galvanizing steel with zinc).
  • Cathodic Protection: Making the structure to be protected the cathode of an electrochemical cell. This forces the structure to be reduced rather than oxidized. There are two main types:
    • Sacrificial Anode: A more reactive metal (e.g., zinc, magnesium, or aluminum) is electrically connected to the protected metal (e.g., a steel pipeline or ship hull). The sacrificial anode corrodes preferentially, protecting the structure.
    • Impressed Current: An external DC power source is used to impress a current onto the structure, forcing it to be a cathode.
  • Inhibitors: Chemicals added to the environment that decrease the rate of corrosion.

solvedExamples.question: Galvanizing steel involves coating it with a layer of zinc. This protects the steel even if the coating is scratched. This is an example of what type of corrosion control?
solvedExamples.explanation: Zinc is more reactive (more anodic) than steel (iron). When the two are in electrical contact in an electrolyte (like rainwater), the zinc will corrode preferentially, acting as a sacrificial anode to protect the steel. This is a form of cathodic protection, in addition to the barrier protection the coating provides.
